===

1313353150460497923 [2020-10-06] @BLUNDERBUSSTED 💜 10 [(SEED) type=semantic_search]
i love you guys, i live this space on twitter i inhabit. weird minds, creative, supportive. right mix of shitposting and effortposting. people looking for a confederacy of friends and attention without pretense or too many airs. good people, you.

===

1389186670000545807 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 35 🔁 5
this is a @Knipps appreciation thread: sharing what I’ve learned from him about the Art of the Reply. In case you didn’t know, Knipps is the BEST REPLY GUY: 
https://t.co/1yd8Tpdegd
  [Quoting @tasshinfogleman: @Knipps your brand is BEST REPLY GUY]

===

1389187344293670915 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 12
here are some of the inspirations he shared:Jeff Bezos: "It’s harder to be kind than clever"
↓
1389187345044361221 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 10
https://t.co/ba2FvuaoB3
  [Quoting Tweet 551130145340153856 (missing)]
↓
1389187347263201280 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 27
this quote from Tyler Cowen on the Tim Ferriss show (#413, 1:19:22):https://t.co/5oyZum4Stw https://t.co/tiaS7Eyfyr
Images:
  - [Image #0] The image is a text-based image showing a transcript of a conversation between Tim Ferriss (TF) and Tyler Cowen (TC). The text reads:
    
    TF - What does that look like - being kinder to people? Why did that become a focus for you?
    
    TC - If you can be encouraging in a non-trivial way - it can really mean a lot to people, and it takes several kinds of effort. There's effort in the moment, but also the skill of how to sincerely have a sense of what would be the encouraging thing to say - and it seems to me that's greatly undersupplied in the world. Like some of the things that are undersupplied are just people telling people what they're good at, which happens plenty, but really kind of accurate and incisive. "This is what you're good at and why" - greatly undersupplied. Supplying people, especially younger people, visions of what they could be - greatly undersupplied.
    
    To recreate this image, you would need to copy the exact text and formatting, including the attribution of the speakers (TF and TC) and the content of their conversation, and present it on a plain white background.
↓
1389187348420829186 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 12
(Tyler goes on to explain in that episode that that's why he does his EV grants... the money is symbolic, a way to encourage people and make it real for them that he believes in them)
↓
1389187349305860096 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 12
"People share things that make them look 💯"https://t.co/qUUyJa4K3Q
  [Quoting Tweet 1387463948312719370 (missing)]
↓
1389188149016936452 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 10
here's some of the wisdom he shared with me about excellent reply game:
↓
1389188149826441216 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 15
"Reply game is an infinite game, akin to improv, 'yes and'"
↓
1389188151072247809 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 15
"Make it easy for people to understand/continue the game/dance of replies"
↓
1389188151973908481 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 17
"people LOVE to be showered in likes. And they cost nothing"
↓
1389188152800288768 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 13
Embody: "Energy, enthusiasm, & energy. Gratitude. Making people feel appreciated. Warm & fuzzies."
↓
1389188153630658566 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 11 [(SEED) type=semantic_search]
"Make it relevant with universal feelings. Helps to know who you're replying to"
↓
1389188154494697474 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 15
"Mirroring also very good. Should not only be fun for you, but recipient. I used to make a lot of jokes that were to entertain me, that no one else got. Everyone wants to be in on the joke"
↓
1389188155425890305 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 14
"Sometimes a good reply is finding that thread from 3 days (or months) ago"
↓
1389188156252172291 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 10
"I like to share relevant threads, but most folks don’t want to work for a response"
↓
1389188157061713921 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 13
"QT is good if you have a lot of thoughts to add, to avoid clogging someone else’s mentions. and it goes without saying: no dunking"
↓
1389188157997035523 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 12
"you can’t keep every conversation going indefinitely, you’ll go mad"
↓
1389188158810693636 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 14
i asked @Knipps about some of his favorite replies. here's my favorite of the ones he shared: https://t.co/N97LUs1o1r
  [Quoting Tweet 1373393632930131968 (missing)]
↓
1389188160010309633 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 12
and some final words of wisdom from Knipps: "I’m also still learning..."
↓
1389188160916279297 [2021-05-03] @tasshinfogleman 💜 18
if you haven't already followed @Knipps, can't recommend following him enough! he's friendly and fun to be around and I've learned a lot from his example. here's to cultivating the art of the reply together, and being better friends!
↓
1462699512300916736 [2021-11-22] @tasshinfogleman 💜 6
@Knipps https://t.co/VPhQcpoS3X
  [Quoting Tweet 1459247300119707652 (missing)]

===

1450685539825319938 [2021-10-20] @visakanv 💜 458 🔁 43 [(SEED) type=semantic_search]
in this house we believe in:

- let curiosity drive
- QT to support, never to dunk
- joke about outcomes you want
- introduce people to each other
- practice good reply game
- give sincere compliments
- experiment with frames
- baby steps
- do 100 thing
- shitposting
- ayy lmao

===

1472956318105452547 [2021-12-20] @AskYatharth 💜 5 [(SEED) type=quote_of_root]
it’s strange, right? what’s wrong right making this explicit

it’s fun as an injoke seriousshitpost in its context

it’s even fine as a set of guidelines for a group of rats https://t.co/LhmmHtE2Kn
  [Quoting @MasterTimBlais: IN THIS HOUSE WE  - REPLY like it's IMPROV - hold our beliefs LOOSELY - be FRIENDLY, AMBITIOUS NERDS - FLIRT with ABANDON - MUTE POLITICAL RETWEETS - AMPLIFY the GOOD - DISTRUST UNHAPPY INTELLIGENCE  and always ALWAYS like before replying]
↓
1472956326405976071 [2021-12-20] @AskYatharth 💜 3
but there’s something about group of people holding up “REPLY like its IMPROV” as a value that can corrupt the whole vibe
↓
1472956329560096775 [2021-12-20] @AskYatharth 💜 3
it’s the kind of thing where rigour is brought to an intermediate value in a way that allows for the wholer thing to be forgotten or lost

and it seems *fine* in the moment
↓
1472956332701470720 [2021-12-20] @AskYatharth 💜 3
but eventually people who don’t understand the whole thing very well but do understand goodharting this thing well take over

the others downscale their engagement or leave

nothing particularly explicit
↓
1472956335448891392 [2021-12-20] @AskYatharth 💜 2
in its place is a vibe that is only a touch more desperate than the original, but the flavour is visible to see

this is what happened with the circling institute community and a many others

https://t.co/NgVRplq6mf
  [Quoting @AskYatharth: @magghu Personally, it can feel like these people have an axe to grind. They found some modicum of control and expression here, if not in their normal social worlds and normal lives. Then there is a defence of it. “You’re doing this wrong!”]
↓
1472962891376742405 [2021-12-20] @AskYatharth 
the people that remain remain with a touch more desperation

i would know

im one of them https://t.co/GcdgTWX73k

1472962894388240399 [2021-12-20] @AskYatharth 💜 1
this is partly a joke

there’s nothing actually wrong with orienting towards being rigorously sensitive

but . . . there’s something about it that is compatible with and can mask a certain desperate goodharting
↓
1472962918002089987 [2021-12-20] @AskYatharth 💜 1
there’s something about that desperation that is familiar to me

to the extent it’s been part of me, i smell it with a certain clarity 

to the extent ive participated in those dynamics as someone who did not know how to be *real*, i can see the corruption it can produce https://t.co/pXSGSGJAWj

  - [Image #0] The image is a screenshot of a text conversation. The text is transcribed as follows:
    
    - 7:41 PM: ">What's the style / I dont know how to explain, but this sentence is actually part of it"
    - 7:41 PM: "dang"
    - 7:42 PM: "Heh 'rigorous sensitivity' is a good descriptor actually"
    - 7:43 PM: "reallyyyyy"
    - 7:44 PM: 
      - "Yes."
      - "Basically, ANYTHING that has positive social returns is ripe for goodharting"
      - "And it gets goodharted at the bottom well before the people at the top notice"

1472962921412059136 [2021-12-20] @AskYatharth 
none of this is a *serious* problem

to take it seriously is to kind of contribute to the problem itself

instead, there is a certain lightness called for instead. the working out of something through illegibility and ambiguity https://t.co/BKAi1SrazE
  [Quoting @Malcolm_Ocean: @AskYatharth Game A is almost entirely composed of defenses against Game A  (viewed through a certain lens)]
↓
1472962924981456901 [2021-12-20] @AskYatharth 💜 1
this is part of the tacit reason illegibility gets talked about 

there is a virgin defence-through-illegibility and a chad defence-through-illegibility and the chad one can almost misunderstand the own ways it works
↓
1472962927527448576 [2021-12-20] @AskYatharth 
this is part of the tacit reason illegibility gets talked about 

there is a virgin defence-through-illegibility and a chad defence-through-illegibility and the chad one can almost misunderstand the own ways it works https://t.co/Exc4zwQTjB

1539950758317154311 [2022-06-23] @peakexperiments 💜 2 [(SEED) type=quote_of_root]
Gonna try to start living my online life this way https://t.co/VM1V0hS7ZR
  [Quoting @MasterTimBlais: IN THIS HOUSE WE  - REPLY like it's IMPROV - hold our beliefs LOOSELY - be FRIENDLY, AMBITIOUS NERDS - FLIRT with ABANDON - MUTE POLITICAL RETWEETS - AMPLIFY the GOOD - DISTRUST UNHAPPY INTELLIGENCE  and always ALWAYS like before replying]

===

1605469746882678784 [2022-12-21] @christineist 💜 32 🔁 1
Pattern language friends—  what are the patterns that show up here/in this part of twitter that make the space feel alive, and which make the space feel dead? 

comment ideas on top level tweet and I will attach them along with my own brainstorm in the thread
↓
1605470316536352769 [2022-12-21] @christineist 💜 7
We have memes. Memes are effectively packaging and "naming" patterns in a way that is easily shareable 

https://t.co/jigZMcFG7b
  [Quoting @gnostrils: all right, i guess it's time for me to share my list of ingroup memes that i've been collecting all year  tell me which ones i'm missing and i'll add them to this list  in no particular order... 🧵]
↓
1605471251274747904 [2022-12-21] @christineist 💜 8
I would argue that "good reply game" is a pattern. It has elements (accounts, tweets), relationships (mutuals, replies), space (twitter), repeated events (replies), etc

https://t.co/KLlRlYREx1
  [Quoting @visakanv: There is an art to replying and commenting, and probably like 60-70% of people I’ve seen on the internet fail at it. The important thing is not to speak your mind, but to “support” the OP. You can support them by disagreeing well & you can “mis-support”  them by agreeing stupidly]
↓
1605471492354953217 [2022-12-21] @christineist 💜 8 [(SEED) type=quote_of_root]
there is some sense of "norms" that also serve as "shared language" or "common patterns"

https://t.co/psaPLwb6Ry
  [Quoting @MasterTimBlais: IN THIS HOUSE WE  - REPLY like it's IMPROV - hold our beliefs LOOSELY - be FRIENDLY, AMBITIOUS NERDS - FLIRT with ABANDON - MUTE POLITICAL RETWEETS - AMPLIFY the GOOD - DISTRUST UNHAPPY INTELLIGENCE  and always ALWAYS like before replying]
↓
1605472267298754560 [2022-12-21] @christineist 💜 6
Highest level pattern: People come to twitter to tweet and reply to each other's tweets

Within twitterspace: Ability to thread, Ability to branch off any particular node, Temporality of feed & profile posts

Within twitterevents: tweeting, making threads, replies...
↓
1605472845747740673 [2022-12-21] @christineist 💜 6
more twitter-space-events: repeated online and IRL events. Picnics, vibecamp, bigger parties, get togethers, discord servers, book clubs, birthday parties, group chats, twitterspaces, interintellect salons
↓
1605473360153939970 [2022-12-21] @christineist 💜 6
Ease of entry and access. Anyone can reply to anyones tweets (given they are public). You can say anything (mostly lol). 

There is no dislike button, so the worst that can happen is you get ignored. I want to say that the lack of dislike actually does a lot of heavy lifting.
↓
1605473907418353664 [2022-12-21] @christineist 💜 6
Things that make this space feel alive: 
When you get your first mutual interaction. when someone compliments you on your tweet. a voice responds from the void, and it is friendly. Close quarters with brilliant / genius minds.
↓
1605474260297740288 [2022-12-21] @christineist 💜 8
Things that make things feel dead: 
boring content, bad engagement, non-thoughtful replies, lack of people creating or thinking on their own, judgment, shaming, acrimonious/combative discussion, riffing that goes too far
↓
1605475713460473857 [2022-12-21] @christineist 💜 7
Oh, one of my favorite patterns in this space is people who build in public, make things, share progress, and show it to friends. There is the music channel, the occasional "look I made this" photo, tweeting of how things are going, Make 100 Things
↓
1605475848210894855 [2022-12-21] @christineist 💜 6
Another pattern— lots of programmers. Lots of male programmers.
↓
1605476343994388481 [2022-12-21] @christineist 💜 5
Going into communities as patterns... rationalist, post rationalist, EA, IFS, meditation/spirituality, Qualia research institute, VC and startup area, therapy and life coaching, Interintellect, the stoa, Open AI, Blogs with community followings (ribbonfarm, astral codex ten, etc)
↓
1605476611721084929 [2022-12-21] @christineist 💜 4
If we were to follow the prescribed way and pick out the nearest larger patterns that this part of twitter falls under, and pick out the major patterns underneath this space, what would those be?
↓
1605642036383621120 [2022-12-21] @christineist 💜 2
Overlapping venn diagrams of mutuals/sim clusters that regularly engage with eachother. Often created through little bursts of replies-to-replies within the comments section of a top level tweet from a larger account everyone follows.

https://t.co/up23zqW7nn
  [Quoting Tweet 1605535816956006409 (missing)]

1702254777961254956 [2023-09-14] @Tangrenin 💜 17
*always like before replying*I just realized another reason I like this norm:+It encourages a way of seeing what's likeable about each tweet, what it addsBut also!+It gets you to only reply to tweets you like!If you'd rather not like a post, mb you don't want to reply to it
↓
1702254780217798963 [2023-09-14] @Tangrenin 💜 1
(obviously there are tons of nuances for this last point and this general "you" mostly means "me" 😅)
↓
1702254781962527223 [2023-09-14] @Tangrenin 💜 6 🔁 1 [(SEED) type=quote_of_root]
So "always like before replying" is about friendliness and improv's 'yes-and-ing' AND ALSO about amplify the good! It's very cool to notice now how these precepts can "secretly" all stem from and to each other in resonance 😌tpot is nice 🔥https://t.co/wITCSCmBiB

1751662641880162582 [2024-01-28] @strangestloop 💜 44
I'm fresh off of a call with a friend and I want to think out loud about something that is core to my twitter experience that I may not have talked about much on here: I want to be seen. I want you to have an understanding of who I am, one that resonates with how I see myself.
↓
1751663712014893496 [2024-01-28] @strangestloop 💜 16 [(SEED) type=quote_of_semantic_search]
How do I see myself? I articulated much of it in my pinned tweet. Some of those labels feel truer than others at different times. Right now, I feel most secure in my creativity and curiosity. I feel least secure in my intentionality and thoughtfulness.
https://t.co/y1AvHN0yMR
  [Quoting @strangestloop: intended vibes: friendly, intentional, thoughtful, playful, empathetic, authentic, creative, optimistic, curious, kind 💪🦚]
↓
1751667976808415418 [2024-01-28] @strangestloop 💜 9
Of course, I cannot control how you see me, nor would I want to. You see me how you see me. Some of you extrapolate my virtues and some of you extrapolate my flaws. I don't hold any resentment about this. I also do this to some people.
https://t.co/OoIAdDD5QF
  [Quoting @strangestloop: A person's biggest fans overemphasize their virtues and discount their flaws. A person's biggest haters overemphasize their flaws and discount their virtues. Both perspectives fail to see the person as they are, they don't recognize the person's full and irreducible complexity.]
↓
1751669060310347876 [2024-01-28] @strangestloop 💜 7
Sometimes I tweet things that evoke a lot of hurt or anger or sadness or ridicule from readers. These tweets point to blindspots that I have: too much focus on myself at the expense of others, lack of thoughtfulness and consideration of how my words will be received.
↓
1751671634807709879 [2024-01-28] @strangestloop 💜 6
I own these mistakes, I own the hurt that they cause. I'm sorry that these tweets are so hurtful. I want to have the foresight to not cause such hurt. These tweets show me that I have room to grow, they help me better understand and internalize the impact that my words have.
↓
1751673270628130947 [2024-01-28] @strangestloop 💜 6
Just as some readers don't feel seen when they read these tweets, I don't feel seen when the tweets are used to draw conclusions about me that do not resonate whatsoever with how I see myself, how I show up in life outside of twitter, what is in my heart, but...
↓
1751673761210777978 [2024-01-28] @strangestloop 💜 3
...I know, understand, and accept that those conclusions are ultimately my fault. I went first by sharing the hurtful tweets, by failing to anticipate how people would receive these tweets and acting accordingly. I believe that who goes first in a chain of hurt matters a lot.
↓
1751675436713566698 [2024-01-28] @strangestloop 💜 6
I believe that here on twitter, we all teach each other how we want to be seen and what makes us feel seen. My tweets teach you how I want to be seen, my profile picture teaches you how I want to be seen, my handle teaches you how I want to be seen.
↓
1751676446081233067 [2024-01-28] @strangestloop 💜 7
It's great that we get to teach each other how we want to be seen. When this is communicated effectively, everyone gets to decide for themselves whether they want to participate in this seeing, whether they want to go along with the seeing frame that is presented to them.
↓
1751678232754000067 [2024-01-28] @strangestloop 💜 9
I'm grateful for the immense amount of grace that has been extended to me in my most unaware moments on twitter, and I'm grateful for the attention and care you're giving me in this moment by reading this thread.

1769002376927514714 [2024-03-16] @visakanv 💜 18

↓
1769003225997267354 [2024-03-16] @visakanv 💜 25

↓
1769003750557966429 [2024-03-16] @visakanv 💜 18 🔁 1
language is always being renegotiated in real time. we can make it better or worse. clear language allows people to think clear thoughts. when terminology gets clouded, it can be useful to redefine things from scratch. clear thinkers and writers are a huge public good

1769004293913203096 [2024-03-16] @visakanv 💜 13
media is the means by which we interface with the wider world beyond our immediate senses. it becomes more powerful every year, it shapes our thoughts, our sense of ourselves, our peers, the world, our identities, everything. navigating it well requires several kinds of finesse
↓
1769004649439174819 [2024-03-16] @visakanv 💜 12
communication was always challenging; even in the ancestral environment people were surely struggling with miscommunication. it's harder than ever in the modern media environment. it's magic that anybody understands anyone ever. we are too quick to blame each other when it fails
↓
1769005220229448132 [2024-03-16] @visakanv 💜 11
perceptions rarely capture the truth of anything. we seldom think to question our perceptions. of course nobody has the time to reexamine everything all the time, but we can learn to at least step lightly. it might seem like a lot of work but it's v gratifying, essay to explain

1769005789664977251 [2024-03-16] @visakanv 💜 11 🔁 1

1769006450842501283 [2024-03-16] @visakanv 💜 15 🔁 1

My single rule for productive Twitter discussions:

Start every single reply with a point of agreement.  It disarms the combative impulse on both sides, and forces you to try to interpret their words in the most sensible possible way.

rating.reasoning_summary: This strand documents the codification and evolution of 'TPOT social norms' as a boundary object, anchored by MasterTimBlais's viral 2021 'IN THIS HOUSE WE' tweet. The discourse is primarily constructive rather than dialectical—people adopt, celebrate, and occasionally critique these norms, but the core artifact remains stable. The strand shows high cohesion (recurring references over 4 years) but low conceptual evolution (the norms are repeated, not refined). Utility is medium: high for scene insiders (provides shared language and identity markers) but low for outsiders (lacks actionable frameworks beyond vibes). Yatharth's 2021 critique about 'goodharting' represents the only substantive challenge, warning that explicit norms can corrupt organic culture, but this thread is largely ignored by the community.

essential_tweets.annotation: Pre-history: Strangestloop articulates aspirational vibes (2020) before they become codified norms
Early pedagogy: Tasshin's thread on 'Art of the Reply' (May 2021) establishes reply-game as teachable skill
Visa's proto-version (Oct 2021) showing norms emerging organically across multiple accounts
The Artifact: MasterTimBlais's canonical 'IN THIS HOUSE WE' tweet becomes the definitive boundary object
Application: Grin_io integrates norms into 'ingroup network state' vision, linking social tech to physical spaces
The Critique: Yatharth's warning about goodharting and corruption through explicit codification (only dialectical moment)
Pattern Language: Christine frames norms as architectural patterns that make Twitter 'feel alive' (2022)
Welcoming Ritual: Rich Decibels uses norms to onboard newcomers, showing they function as identity markers
Theoretical Synthesis: Visa elevates 'reply game' to universal principle ('second note changes first')
Persistence Check: 2025 request for 'tpot norms' confirms the artifact remains canonical reference 4 years later
